does something specific it's there tends to be very specialized and only do one
specific task notice that I'm not saying that they are specific processes or
executables in Miraz one they you they tend it to be one node pair process and
then there were some tricks like not--let's and other concepts that you could put more than one node in a process but in Ross - they are just
pieces of software that do something that communicate with other nodes and they can add when you're writing them
you don't know if they're gonna be in separate processes or not and when you deploy your application you decide how
they map like which nodes going in which process and so on so these are nodes they're only three nodes in Dali
but a typical robot may have dozens even hundreds of nodes running at the same time how is information flowing between
the nodes so we have mainly two pipes of information one is the laser scans
they're flowing from the lid from the laser to the follow node and the other one is the commands going towards the
differential drive and these are what we call in Ross topics so top a topic is
basically a channel of information and you have a publisher and a subscriber it's a pub sub mechanism it's many to
many so you can have many nodes publishing in the same topic and many nodes also subscribing to that same
topic and they don't care about where the information is coming they just care that it's coming it's a certain message
of a certain type that is coming through a certain channel which is that topic this is the most bay
type of communication supported in Ross or Russ - but there are other two main
methods of communication one is what we call services that is more of a request
response kind of thing and there is also actions which is more like a request for something that may take a while and
we'll send you periodic updates of what how it's progressing and eventually it's gonna say that it's complete and you can
also cancel it so it's a little bit more complex for our example today I'll be only using topics because it's the most

tested on things like nuclear power plants and air airplanes so it's very
trustworthy it's real time save it handles quality of service right like when Ross was written it was written
originally based on one rub which was a the pr2 robots that had two arms and moved on wheels and nowadays
it's used for all these different applications and it doesn't really handle cases like you have 100 robots
with very little processing power each one of them and they are communicating over choppy Wi-Fi it's not a use case
that was one can handle very well but that rust you can and because it can handle quality of service all because
it's building on top of DDS so this communication layer is the main thing that is changing from res one - Russ -
and another interesting thing about it is that instead of building the whole
stack from scratch in each language so Russ has clients for any language that you can imagine because people just
write clients for it but in for Russ - we created well not we build rusting
because I wasn't there at the time there was a thin layer of a wrapper in see
that exposes the DDS implementations which DDS is a protocol so there are
many different vendors out there some are open-source some are proprietary and we just created this abstraction so at
runtime you can decide well I compile time you can decide which DDS implementation you're going to use for
your application if you prefer when you have the license for another one you can just use that and then on top of this C
layer you can build thinner clients for each language so the the core russ team
is maintaining the C++ and Python layers but there are people in the community already contributing with Java rust
c-sharp you name it people if people are interested in programming robots in
